questions.text: Which nerve passes through the foramen marked red in the given image:
questions.solution: The marked structure is mandibular foramen and inferior alveolar nerve passes through it.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image :
questions.solution:
The condition in the given image is acanthosis nigricans.

It is a skin condition is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.

The causal mechanism is due to the secretion of epidermal growth factor in the region involved. It can be benign or malignancy-associated.

Benign acanthosis nigricans is often associated with obesity or insulin resistance, it is common and usually mild.

Malignancy associated acanthosis nigricans is much less common. It is usually associated with gastric carcinoma, lung carcinoma, and uterine carcinoma.

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

  • Drugs such as Nicotinic acid used to treat hyperlipidemia 
  • Sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratosis

questions.text: A patient presents with severe joint disease and symptoms that mimic rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis. Aspirated crystals appear to be rhomboid, 0.5 to 5 μm in the greatest dimension, and positively birefringent.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history and investigations are suggestive of Calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD).

  • Calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD), also known as pseudo-gout and chondrocalcinosis, usually occurs in individuals older than 50 years of age and becomes more common with increasing age.
  • CPPD is classified into the sporadic (idiopathic), hereditary, and secondary types.
  • The disease is caused by germline mutations in the pyrophosphate transport channel.
  • The secondary form is associated with previous joint damage, hyperparathyroidism, hemochromatosis, hypomagnesemia, hypothyroidism, ochronosis, and diabetes.
  • Individual crystals are rhomboid, 0.5 to 5 μm in the greatest dimension, and are positively birefringent. Inflammation, if present, is usually milder than in gout.
  • CPPD may produce acute, subacute, or chronic arthritis that can be confused with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.
  • The joint involvement may be monoarticular or polyarticular; the knees, followed by the wrists, elbows, shoulders, and ankles, are most commonly affected.

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding

Gout

Pseudogout

Crystal composition

Uric acid

Calcium pyrophosphate

Shape

Needle like

Rhomboid

Birefringence pattern

Negative

Weak positive

Most commonly affected joint

1st MTP

Knee

X-ray findings

Periarticular erosions with overhanging margins

Chondrocalcinosis

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman came to the local emergency department with severe headache and stiffness of the neck. The CSF specimen is cloudy. While in the emergency room, an intern performs gram stain of the CSF but by mistake forgets the step in which iodine is added. Assuming that the women has meningitis caused by streptococcus pneumoniae,  how would the bacteria on the intern’s slide appear?

choices.text: No gram stain results would be obtained due to lysis of all cells

questions.solution:
In the above question, the intern forgot to add iodine, i.e, the second step of gram staining. As a result, the purple iodine-dye complex will not form, and the entire crystal violet dye will wash away during the decolorization step. Now when the safranin is added, all the cells will stain red.

The various steps in gram staining are as follows:

  1. The crystal violet dye stains all cells purple.
  2. The iodine solution (a mordant) is added to form a crystal violet–iodine complex. At the end of this step, all cells continue to appear purple.
  3. In the decolorization step, the organic solvent, such as acetone or ethanol, extracts the blue dye complex from the lipid-rich, thin-walled gram-negative bacteria to a greater degree than from the lipid-poor, thick-walled gram-positive bacteria. At the end of this step, the gram-negative organisms appear colorless; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.
  4. The red dye safranin (counterstain) stains the decolorized gram-negative cells red/pink; the gram-positive bacteria remain purple.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains These include Eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, Congo red, etc. and are mostly used to stain pathological specimens.
Basic stains.

1.    Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in counterstaining in quellung reaction of streptococcus pneumoniae.  

2.    Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction of anthrax bacilli
Neutral stains

1.    Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

2.    Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and some other spirochete and protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contains more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: Used to distinguish cells by cell-wall type. To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain: Used to distinguish acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast cells. Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid – fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Used for rapid scanning of the smear, where the AFB appear fluorescent green against a black background Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "Chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (Anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–Starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor White Staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain Calcofluor white, which greatly enhances visibility of fungal element in tissue or other specimens. It is especially useful for the identification of Mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.   It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For Cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the first-line drug used in the treatment of Trigeminal neuralgia ?

choices.text: It is a GABAc receptor modulator
It can lead to hyponatremia in the elderly

questions.solution:
Carbamazepine is the primary agent for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia which is a Sodium-channel blocker.

It slows the recovery rate of voltage-activated sodium channels from their inactivated state.

Carbamazepine is most effective in complex partial seizures. It is also used in GTCS and simple partial seizures, trigeminal and related neuralgias, manic depressive psychosis.

Carbamazepine potentiates the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can result in water retention with decreased osmolarity and hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients with cardiac disease.Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause leukopenia, aplastic anemia, or hepato-toxicity and hyponatremia in the elderly.

Idiosyncratic blood dyscrasias with carbamazepine, include fatal cases of aplastic anaemia and agranulocytosis. The most common idiosyncratic reaction is an erythematous skin rash. It can rarely cause Steven Johnson Syndrome.

Mechanism of action of some common antiepileptics:

Mechanism of action Antiepileptics
Sodium-channel blockers

Phenytoin

questions.text: Obtaining sexual gratification using enema is known as
questions.solution:
Klismaphilia refers to obtaining sexual gratification using enema.

  • Option A: Urolagnia: Sexual excitement associated with sight or thought of urine or urination.
  • Option B: Caprolagnia: Sexual excitement associated with sight or thought of faeces or defecation.
  • Option D: Undinism: Sexual gratification obtained by seeing act of urination or by being urinated upon.

questions.text: A patient developed confusion, hydrophobia, and photophobia a week after a dog bite, he was diagnosed with rabies. The case fatality rate is _______
questions.solution:
The case fatality rate of rabies is almost 100%.

The case fatality rate is the killing power of a disease, it is closely related to virulence.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?
questions.solution:
The mass has spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension, so its Stage 1B.

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:

  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumour seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality.
  • JNA accounts for only 0.05% of all head and neck tumours.

Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Modified sessions, et al)

I A: Limited to the nose and/or nasopharyngeal vault
I B: Extension into ≥ 1 sinus
II A: Minimal extension into pterygopalatine fossa
II B: Full occupation of pterygopalatine fossa with or without erosion of orbital bones
II C: Infratemporal fossa with or without cheek or posterior to pterygoid plates
III A: Erosion of skull base-minimal intracranial
III B: Erosion of skull base-extensive intracranial with or without cavernous sinus

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially?
questions.solution:
The above image shows penetrating injury by a metallic fish-hook. In the case of penetrating injuries, the foreign body should not be removed initially.

  • Visual acuity of both injured and normal eye is assessed.
  • The foreign body should not be removed manually, as it may cause further injury.
  • A CT scan is performed to rule out intraorbital, intracranial or intraocular FBs or penetration.
  • MRI is contraindicated for metallic foreign bodies.
  • Prophylactic systemic antibiotics are prescribed.
  • Once, the extent of the injury is ascertained, the foreign body is removed under surgical exploration and repair.

questions.text: What can be the likely cause of ascites if the serum ascites-to-albumin gradient (SAAG ) is 1.5g/dl and the ascitic protein level is 3g/dl?
questions.solution:
The cause of ascites when the serum ascites-to-albumin gradient (SAAG) is 1.5g/dl and the ascitic protein level is 3g/dl is Congestive heart failure.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG):

  • Calculated by subtracting the ascitic albumin concentration from the serum albumin level.
  • Reflects the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids
  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

Ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology, in cases with high-SAAG (≥1.1):

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing passage of protein into the ascites. eg. cardiac ascites
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. cirrhosis

The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is the most reli­able method to differentiate causes of ascites due to portal hyper­tension from those not due to portal hypertension.

questions.text: The diagnosis based on the gross picture of Gall bladder is
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the gallbladder is of Cholesterolosis Gallbladder also known as Strawberry gallbladder.

It reveals:

  • Brick red GB mucosa with Bright yellow flecks of lipid.
  • Multiple cholesterol polyps studding the gallbladder wall.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation.
questions.solution:
During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth is suctioned first and then the nares, in order to decrease the risk of aspiration. A 12 or 14 french suction catheter is used, with the suction pressure kept between 80-100mmHg.

Routine suctioning of the trachea during neonatal resuscitation is not recommended. The suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided if not indicated specifically, as it can produce a vagal response due to stimulation in the posterior pharynx, resulting in apnea and/or bradycardia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male has pain and swelling in the knee joint.  Synovial fluid on polarized light microscopy demonstrated positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals. This is due to the deposition of _______
questions.solution:
The given case is suggestive of pseudogout and in the study of synovial aspirate on polarized light, the crystals appear as positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals is due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals.

Crystals on Polarised Microscopy
Gout Pseudogout
Negatively birefringent Positively birefringent
Needle shaped Rhomboid crystals
Na urate (Sodium urate) Calcium pyrophosphate

 

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

questions.text: IUCD having the longest life span is _____________
questions.solution:
CuT 380 A has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paraguard): It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. Hence the Copper T-380A has been able to achieve superior contraception while maintaining a similar side-effect profile

The Copper T-380A has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the life span of the Copper T-380A.

The frame of the Copper T-380A is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

IUCD Life span
Cu T 380A 10 years
CuT 200 3 years
Multi loaded Cu 250  3 years
LNG IUS /Mirena

5 years
Progestasert 1 year
Nova-T 5 years

questions.text: According to sigmund freud in the interpretation of dreams, which of the following terms refers to the representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected with the idea or object being represented?
questions.solution:
Symbolism refers to the representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected with the idea or object being represented.

According to the Interpretation of dreams written by sigmund freud, dreams represent unconscious wishes or thoughts which are not accepted by the conscious mind. They manifest through the following mechanisms:

  • Symbolism: Representation of highly charged ideas or objects through innocent images that are in some way connected. 
  • Displacement: Transfer of mental energy from one object to a substitute or symbolic representation of the object. 
  • Condensation: Mechanism by which multiple unconscious wishes combine into a single image. Converse to it is called irradiation or diffusion, where, one unconscious wish gets distributed into multiple images. 
  • Projection: Attributing one’s own unacknowledged feelings to others. 
  • Secondary elaboration: Process by which the ego organizes illogical, bizarre and absurd images into a more coherent form in dreams. 

 

Related Pearl: Contributions by Sigmund Freud

Contributions of Sigmund Freud to the field of psychiatry

  • Free association
  • Interpretation of dreams
  • Psychoanalysis
  • Psycho-sexual development 
  • Psychodynamic theory 
  • Topographic theory of the mind-unconscious, preconscious, conscious
  • Structural theory of mind- id, ego, superego
  • Cocaine in psychiatry
